Therapist: It's really common to struggle with accepting compliments or acknowledging our own achievements, Marcus. This is something we can continue to work on together. I'm curious, what has it been like for you to start identifying these cognitive distortions in your own thinking? How does it feel to recognize these patterns?

Patient: It's been eye-opening, honestly. I knew I had a lot of negative thoughts, but I didn't realize how much they were distorting my view of myself and the world around me. It's a little overwhelming to think about changing these patterns, but I'm also feeling hopeful that it's possible to change.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Marcus. Recognizing these patterns is the first step towards changing them. And you're right, it can feel overwhelming at first to think about changing long-standing thought patterns. That's why we take it one step at a time in CBT.

As we continue working together, we'll start to identify specific goals for our work together. These goals will be based on what's most important to you and what changes you want to make in your life. From what you've shared so far, it sounds like some potential goals could be related to improving your self-esteem, managing depressive symptoms, and developing healthier coping strategies. What are your thoughts on that?

Patient: Those all sound like great goals to me. I definitely want to work on improving my self-esteem and finding healthier ways to cope with my depression. I'd also like to work on my relationships, especially with my partner. I know my depression has been hard on her, and I want to be able to show up more fully in our relationship.

Therapist: Those are wonderful goals, Marcus. We can absolutely work on improving your self-esteem, developing healthier coping strategies, and strengthening your relationships, particularly with your partner. As we continue to explore these areas, we'll break them down into smaller, more specific goals that feel achievable.

One important aspect of CBT is the use of homework assignments between sessions. Homework helps you practice the skills we discuss in therapy and apply them to your daily life. It's a way of extending the work we do in session to the rest of your week.

Some examples of homework assignments could be continuing to keep a thought record, practicing challenging cognitive distortions, or engaging in activities that support your therapy goals, like self-care or quality time with your partner. How do you feel about the idea of homework assignments?

Patient: I'm open to the idea of homework. I know that change doesn't happen just in our sessions, it's something I need to work on every day. It might be challenging at times to find the motivation to do the homework, especially when I'm feeling depressed, but I'm willing to give it a try.

Therapist: That's a great attitude, Marcus. You're absolutely right that the real work of therapy happens between sessions, in your daily life. And you're also right that it can be challenging to find motivation when you're feeling depressed. That's something we can problem-solve together.

We'll work together to come up with homework assignments that feel manageable and relevant to your goals. And if you have any trouble with the homework, we can always discuss it in session and make adjustments as needed. The homework is meant to support your progress, not to be a source of stress or guilt.

Patient: That makes sense. I appreciate that we can be flexible with the homework and adjust it as needed. I'm willing to put in the effort, even if it's not always easy.

Therapist: That's wonderful, Marcus. Your willingness to put in effort, even when it's not easy, is a huge strength and will serve you well in this process. As we continue to work together, we'll keep exploring these concepts and developing skills to support your goals.

I'm curious, what thoughts or questions are coming up for you as we discuss these ideas? Is there anything you'd like to explore further or anything that feels unclear?
